Chinese names are given in the traditional order, surnames first, with the exception of scholars who have adopted the Western order of surname last.

Scholars who have adopted the Western order place the surname last.

qg22mj4n.text: Chinese transliterations for personal names, places and titles of works follow the Pinyin system of romanisation, except for words adopted into English and commonly used place names such as Macau (Pinyin: Aomen).
chunks: Chinese transliterations for personal names, places, and titles of works follow the Pinyin system of romanisation.
Words adopted into English and commonly used place names, such as Macau, do not follow the Pinyin system.

qg22mj4n.text: Foreign terms are italicised unless commonly used in English.
chunks: Foreign terms are italicised unless commonly used in English.

z6g9cslc.text: Beginning in the Ming dynasty, Chinese emperors were usually referred to by their reign era names rather than their given names.
chunks: Beginning in the Ming dynasty, Chinese emperors were usually referred to by their reign era names.
Chinese emperors were usually not referred to by their given names beginning in the Ming dynasty.

z6g9cslc.text: Accordingly, the form ‘the Qianlong emperor’ is followed rather than ‘Emperor Qianlong’ because ‘Qianlong’ is the reign era.
chunks: The form 'the Qianlong emperor' is followed rather than 'Emperor Qianlong' because 'Qianlong' is the reign era.

cdr9u9eb.text: The Chinese term ‘ci’ (translated as porcelain in English) refers to all ceramics that are fired at high temperatures, including porcelain and stoneware.
chunks: The Chinese term 'ci' refers to all ceramics that are fired at high temperatures.
The Chinese term 'ci' includes porcelain and stoneware.

cdr9u9eb.text: In the West, the term porcelain refers specifically to white ceramics made with a special type of clay called kaolin and fired to a temperature of about $1300^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$ , which results in a translucent, glassy material that makes a ringing sound when struck.
chunks: In the West, the term porcelain refers specifically to white ceramics made with a special type of clay called kaolin.
Porcelain is fired to a temperature of about 1300 degrees Celsius.
Firing porcelain results in a translucent, glassy material.
The translucent, glassy material makes a ringing sound when struck.

cdr9u9eb.text: Stoneware is used to refer to related ceramics that are similarly hard and dense, but which are made with grey or brown clay, may or may not be white-bodied, do not transmit light, and are fired to a slightly lower temperature of 1000 to $1250^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$ .
chunks: Stoneware refers to related ceramics that are hard and dense.
Stoneware is made with grey or brown clay.
Stoneware may or may not be white-bodied.
Stoneware does not transmit light.
Stoneware is fired to a temperature of 1000 to 1250 degrees Celsius.

cdr9u9eb.text: Ceramics fired below this temperature range are called earthenwares.
chunks: Ceramics fired below this temperature range are called earthenwares.

cdr9u9eb.text: The terms ‘protoporcelain’ or ‘porcellaneous’ are sometimes used to describe early ceramics made with some of the same ingredients and physical characteristics of porcelain.
chunks: The terms 'protoporcelain' or 'porcellaneous' are sometimes used to describe early ceramics made with some of the same ingredients as porcelain.
The terms 'protoporcelain' or 'porcellaneous' are sometimes used to describe early ceramics with some of the same physical characteristics as porcelain.

hw0eizl9.text: Marks
Other character marks and seal marks may have many different meanings: a wish for good luck, a date, a quality comparison, an owner or factory, or an indication for use in a specific setting.
chunks: Other character marks and seal marks may have many different meanings.
Character marks and seal marks may represent a wish for good luck.
Character marks and seal marks may represent a date.
Character marks and seal marks may represent a quality comparison.
Character marks and seal marks may represent an owner or factory.
Character marks and seal marks may represent an indication for use in a specific setting.

hw0eizl9.text: Individual potter's marks are rare on Jingdezhen porcelain, but they occur much more frequently on porcelain from Dehua.
chunks: Individual potter's marks are rare on Jingdezhen porcelain.
Potter's marks occur much more frequently on porcelain from Dehua.

hw0eizl9.text: Marks are usually found on the bottom of a piece, sometimes on the edge or shoulder, or in the centre.
chunks: Marks are usually found on the bottom of a piece.
Marks are sometimes found on the edge or shoulder.
Marks are sometimes found in the centre.

hw0eizl9.text: Many different marks can be found on Chinese porcelain.
chunks: Many different marks can be found on Chinese porcelain.

hw0eizl9.text: The most prevalent in this catalogue are imperial marks that occur on pieces for the court and related institutions from the Ming dynasty onwards.
chunks: Imperial marks are the most prevalent in this catalogue.
Imperial marks occur on pieces for the court and related institutions from the Ming dynasty onwards.

hw0eizl9.text: They usually consist of six characters (sometimes four) in two rows that are read from right to left and from top to bottom, or in seal script within a square.
chunks: They usually consist of six characters in two rows that are read from right to left and from top to bottom.
They sometimes consist of four characters in two rows that are read from right to left and from top to bottom.
They are sometimes written in seal script within a square.

hw0eizl9.text: The first two characters indicate the dynasty (for instance Da Ming, ‘the great Ming dynasty’).
chunks: The first two characters indicate the dynasty.
Da Ming means 'the great Ming dynasty'.

hw0eizl9.text: The next two give the reign name (nian hao) of the ruling emperor, for instance Jiajing, or Wanli.
chunks: The reign name (nian hao) of the ruling emperor is given by the next two.
The reign name could be Jiajing or Wanli.

hw0eizl9.text: The last two characters mean ‘made during the period of ’ (nian zhi).
chunks: The last two characters mean 'made during the period of' (nian zhi).

hw0eizl9.text: This tradition was continued during the Qing dynasty.
chunks: This tradition was continued during the Qing dynasty.

hw0eizl9.text: Imperial Ming and Qing marks also occur on non–imperial wares and even on export porcelain.
chunks: Imperial Ming marks occur on non-imperial wares.
Imperial Qing marks occur on non-imperial wares.
Imperial Ming marks occur on export porcelain.
Imperial Qing marks occur on export porcelain.

img_footnote: Important kiln sites in China中國的重要窯址

hw0eizl9.text: The early modern era was marked by the extension of the Silk Road to Italy and by the beginning of the importation into Europe of Eastern goods in the fourteenth century.
chunks: The early modern era was marked by the extension of the Silk Road to Italy.
The early modern era was marked by the beginning of the importation of Eastern goods into Europe in the fourteenth century.

hw0eizl9.text: Porcelain from China—the first country in the world to produce highfired, glazed ceramics—was one of the most important elements of this trade, which in the sixteenth century had expanded to include vast quantities of tea, silk, lacquer, spices and opium.
chunks: China was the first country in the world to produce high-fired, glazed ceramics.
Porcelain from China was one of the most important elements of this trade.
In the sixteenth century, this trade had expanded to include vast quantities of tea, silk, lacquer, spices, and opium.

hw0eizl9.text: This catalogue and its accompanying exhibition tell the story of this trade, exploring how ceramics from different regions, particularly China and Europe, spread styles, forms and manufacturing technologies across the globe, and in the process dramatically altered the course of European and Asian art.
chunks: This catalogue and its accompanying exhibition tell the story of this trade.
Ceramics from different regions, particularly China and Europe, spread styles, forms, and manufacturing technologies across the globe.
The spread of styles, forms, and manufacturing technologies dramatically altered the course of European and Asian art.

hw0eizl9.text: While we place particular importance on early Ming dynasty blue-and-white porcelain pieces that reached the Ducal court of the Medicis in Florence, and early export goods in the Low Countries, our chronological display begins much earlier, with a rare Tang dynasty blue-and-white water pot and a Yuan dynasty bottle—both from time periods that predate betterknown Ming production.
chunks: Early Ming dynasty blue-and-white porcelain pieces reached the Ducal court of the Medicis in Florence.
Early export goods reached the Low Countries.
The chronological display begins much earlier than the Ming dynasty.
The chronological display includes a rare Tang dynasty blue-and-white water pot.
The chronological display includes a Yuan dynasty bottle.
The Tang dynasty and Yuan dynasty items predate better-known Ming production.

hw0eizl9.text: These ceramics highlight the artistic quality and beauty of Chinese wares, as well as their influence, appreciation and imitation abroad.
chunks: These ceramics highlight the artistic quality and beauty of Chinese wares.
These ceramics highlight the influence of Chinese wares abroad.
These ceramics highlight the appreciation of Chinese wares abroad.
These ceramics highlight the imitation of Chinese wares abroad.

hw0eizl9.text: This international theme is further explored by presenting Ming and Qing dynasty objects that were made for local consumption in China, as well as for export alongside local responses to these wares in Europe, East Asia and Southeast Asia.
chunks: Ming and Qing dynasty objects were made for local consumption in China.
Ming and Qing dynasty objects were made for export.
Local responses to Ming and Qing dynasty wares existed in Europe.
Local responses to Ming and Qing dynasty wares existed in East Asia.
Local responses to Ming and Qing dynasty wares existed in Southeast Asia.

hw0eizl9.text: In so doing, we move beyond the better-known influences of export to the West by including regional varieties of, for example, celadon ware in Korea and Thailand.
chunks: We move beyond the better-known influences of export to the West.
We include regional varieties of celadon ware in Korea.
We include regional varieties of celadon ware in Thailand.

hw0eizl9.text: We would like to thank our exhibition partners, the Asian Civilisations Museum and the Hong Kong Maritime Museum for their generous loans, and for their assistance in organising related public programming and publications.
chunks: We would like to thank our exhibition partners, the Asian Civilisations Museum and the Hong Kong Maritime Museum, for their generous loans.
We would like to thank our exhibition partners for their assistance in organising related public programming and publications.

hw0eizl9.text: As with all UMAG exhibitions, our mission is to engage with audiences through the discussion of materials and techniques, as well as historic and cross-cultural exchanges.
chunks: The mission of UMAG exhibitions is to engage with audiences through the discussion of materials and techniques.
The mission of UMAG exhibitions is to engage with audiences through historic exchanges.
The mission of UMAG exhibitions is to engage with audiences through cross-cultural exchanges.

hw0eizl9.text: We express our gratitude to Robert Black College, The University of Hong Kong, for support of the exhibition on their 50th anniversary.
chunks: We express our gratitude to Robert Black College for support of the exhibition on their 50th anniversary.
Robert Black College is part of The University of Hong Kong.

hw0eizl9.text: Florian Knothe Director, University Museum and Art Gallery, The University of Hong Kong

y91cel1n.text: Chinese porcelain in Europe and Asia
The first Chinese porcelains arrived in Europe in the fourteenth century, when small numbers were presented as rare gifts to the ruling houses of Europe via intermediaries in the Middle East (fig.
chunks: The first Chinese porcelains arrived in Europe in the fourteenth century.
Small numbers of Chinese porcelains were presented as rare gifts to the ruling houses of Europe via intermediaries in the Middle East.

y91cel1n.text: Delicate, nearly transparent and resistant to extreme heat and moisture, they were technologically superior to the thick, low-fired European ceramics made before the eighteenth century, and were regarded as objects of great rarity and luxury.
chunks: Delicate, nearly transparent and resistant to extreme heat and moisture, these ceramics were technologically superior to the thick, low-fired European ceramics made before the eighteenth century.
These ceramics were regarded as objects of great rarity and luxury.

y91cel1n.text: Their construction was so poorly understood that European collectors often had them mounted in gilt silver or gold in a manner similar to naturalia (‘natural wonders’) like ostrich eggs and large shells, which emphasised their preciousness and transformed them into entirely different objects.
chunks: Their construction was so poorly understood that European collectors often had them mounted in gilt silver or gold.
European collectors mounted them in a manner similar to naturalia (‘natural wonders’) like ostrich eggs and large shells.
The mounting emphasised their preciousness and transformed them into entirely different objects.

y91cel1n.text: They were often displayed in cabinets of curiosities: collections of extraordinary objects which, like today's museums, attempted to categorise and tell stories about the wonders of the natural world (fig.
chunks: Extraordinary objects were often displayed in cabinets of curiosities.
Cabinets of curiosities were collections that attempted to categorise and tell stories about the wonders of the natural world.

y91cel1n.text: By the early sixteenth century—after Portugal established trade routes to the Far East and began commercial trade with Asia via Portuguese-controlled ports in Macau, Malacca and Dejima—porcelain became an important component of the wider trade in silk, spices, tea, ivory, metalwork and lacquer between East and West.
chunks: By the early sixteenth century, Portugal established trade routes to the Far East and began commercial trade with Asia via Portuguese-controlled ports in Macau, Malacca, and Dejima.
Porcelain became an important component of the wider trade in silk, spices, tea, ivory, metalwork, and lacquer between East and West.

y91cel1n.text: Major production centres like Jingdezhen in Jiangxi province responded to demand in Europe by producing large amounts of porcelain specifically for export, transported and used as a form of ballast in large merchant ships.
chunks: Major production centres like Jingdezhen in Jiangxi province responded to demand in Europe by producing large amounts of porcelain specifically for export.
The porcelain produced for export was transported and used as a form of ballast in large merchant ships.

y91cel1n.text: New arrivals like the Dutch and British built
The word porcelain originated with the Venetian traveller Marco Polo (1254–1324) when he saw white-bodied ceramics being made in China for the court of Kublai Khan.
chunks: The word porcelain originated with the Venetian traveller Marco Polo.
Marco Polo saw white-bodied ceramics being made in China for the court of Kublai Khan.

y91cel1n.text: He called them porcelanna, Italian for a white seashell, and this soon became the standard term in Europe.
chunks: He called them porcelanna, Italian for a white seashell.
Porcelanna soon became the standard term in Europe.

y91cel1n.text: But China had been producing porcelain of the highest quality for markets across the globe long before the arrival of Europeans.
chunks: China had been producing porcelain of the highest quality for markets across the globe long before the arrival of Europeans.

y91cel1n.text: From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced everything from magnificent display pieces for the imperial court to vast quantities of bowls, plates and dishes intended for everyday use and for export to Southeast Asia, Japan, Korea and the Islamic world.
chunks: From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced magnificent display pieces for the imperial court.
From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced vast quantities of bowls, plates, and dishes intended for everyday use.
From the sixth to twentieth centuries, Chinese kilns produced bowls, plates, and dishes for export to Southeast Asia, Japan, Korea, and the Islamic world.

y91cel1n.text: The appeal of these works lay not just in their technical achievement, but also in their association with Chinese art and culture, long viewed as a source of learning, tradition and vast wealth.
chunks: The appeal of these works lay in their technical achievement.
The appeal of these works lay in their association with Chinese art and culture.
Chinese art and culture have long been viewed as a source of learning, tradition, and vast wealth.

up competing trade networks in the seventeenth century, which stimulated the production of special shapes and patterns for certain countries, as well as commissions from wealthy families who wanted personalised features on their dishes.
The fashion for collecting these objects spread so quickly as to appear almost contagious, and was described by some enthusiasts as la maladie die porcelaine— ‘porcelain-sickness’.
chunks: The fashion for collecting these objects spread so quickly as to appear almost contagious.
The fashion for collecting these objects was described by some enthusiasts as la maladie die porcelaine—‘porcelain-sickness’.

y91cel1n.text: Among the wealthiest collectors this led to the creation of ‘porcelain rooms’, where masses of porcelain wares were displayed together and arranged on mantelpieces, cabinets and

Architect and designer Daniel Marot (1661–1752) is often linked to this late Baroque style.
chunks: Architect and designer Daniel Marot lived from 1661 to 1752.
Daniel Marot is often linked to the late Baroque style.

y91cel1n.text: His designs for several rooms of Kensington Palace demonstrate the typical high-density approach to porcelain display of the late Baroque period (ca.
chunks: His designs for several rooms of Kensington Palace demonstrate the typical high-density approach to porcelain display of the late Baroque period.

y91cel1n.text: The appearance of these objects changed in step with tastes in Europe.
chunks: The appearance of these objects changed in step with tastes in Europe.

y91cel1n.text: At times consumers favoured designs that depicted an exotic East, while at others Western patterns with prominent armorial crests or landscapes and figures taken from prints were preferred.
chunks: Consumers at times favored designs that depicted an exotic East.
Western patterns with prominent armorial crests or landscapes and figures taken from prints were preferred at other times.

y91cel1n.text: European designs were transmitted via a wellestablished trading network which carried models to China, where they were copied onto special services (fig.
chunks: European designs were transmitted via a well-established trading network.
The trading network carried models to China.
The models were copied onto special services.

y91cel1n.text: This often had strange results, such as a Dutch charger with the arms of Amsterdam inscribed ‘AMSTEL DAM’ or a porcelain ewer with the seal of Portugal painted upside down (fig.
chunks: A Dutch charger had the arms of Amsterdam inscribed 'AMSTEL DAM.'
A porcelain ewer had the seal of Portugal painted upside down.

y91cel1n.text: Europeans also affected artistic change by bringing new technologies and techniques to China, such as the famille-rose (‘rose family’ in French) palette, which was employed widely on both domestic and export porcelain.
chunks: Europeans affected artistic change by bringing new technologies and techniques to China.
Europeans introduced the famille-rose palette to China, which means 'rose family' in French.
The famille-rose palette was employed widely on both domestic and export porcelain.

y91cel1n.text: Guiseppe Castiglione (1688–1766), a Jesuit painter patronised by the Kangxi, Yongzheng and Qianlong emperors, famously introduced Western painting techniques such as single-point perspective to Chinese artists, which found expression across a variety of mediums.
chunks: Guiseppe Castiglione was a Jesuit painter patronised by the Kangxi, Yongzheng and Qianlong emperors.
Guiseppe Castiglione famously introduced Western painting techniques such as single-point perspective to Chinese artists.
Western painting techniques found expression across a variety of mediums.

y91cel1n.text: Like all successful inventions, Chinese ceramics inspiredcompetition, at first in Asia and later in Europe.
chunks: Chinese ceramics inspired competition in Asia at first.
Chinese ceramics later inspired competition in Europe.

y91cel1n.text: In the lateTang period, traders from the Middle East brought Chineseporcelains to western Asia, where potters in Iraq copied themas la maladie die porcelaine)。

img_caption: Plate. Jingdezhen, China, 1739–1743. Porcelain with overglaze enamels, diameter $22.9~\mathrm{cm}$ . The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York 碟 $^\circ$ 中國景德鎮，一七三九年至一七四三年。釉上彩瓷，直徑 22.9 厘米。紐約，大都會藝術博物館

y91cel1n.text: The Dutch, exempt from restrictions on trade placed on other European nations by the Japanese authorities, also exposed the Arita potters to Chinese underglaze blue porcelain, which was popular in Europe, so that they could use it as an example in their own work.
chunks: The Dutch were exempt from the trade restrictions placed on other European nations by the Japanese authorities.
The Dutch exposed the Arita potters to Chinese underglaze blue porcelain, which was popular in Europe.
The Arita potters could use Chinese underglaze blue porcelain as an example in their own work.

y91cel1n.text: Some scholars have suggested that English manufacturers may have produced hard-paste porcelain before Böttger, but his factory in Meissen was certainly the first to produce it in large quantities (Queiroz and Agathopoulos 2005).
chunks: Some scholars have suggested that English manufacturers may have produced hard-paste porcelain before Böttger.
The factory of Böttger in Meissen was certainly the first to produce hard-paste porcelain in large quantities.

qzxf4whz.text: Porcelain manufactories in Europe

Portuguese traders were successful in returning home with samples of kaolin, which they discovered in China to be essential in the production of porcelain wares, but Europeans remained ignorant of the techniques and processes involved in the production of porcelain until 1708, when the first European hard-paste porcelain (made from a compound of the feldspathic rock petuntse and kaolin clay fired at around $1400^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\mathrm{)}$ was made in Meissen, Germany by Johann Friedrich Böttger.
chunks: Portuguese traders successfully returned home with samples of kaolin, which they discovered in China to be essential in the production of porcelain wares.
Europeans remained ignorant of the techniques and processes involved in the production of porcelain until 1708.
The first European hard-paste porcelain was made in Meissen, Germany in 1708 by Johann Friedrich Böttger.
European hard-paste porcelain is made from a compound of the feldspathic rock petuntse and kaolin clay fired at around 1400 degrees Celsius.

qzxf4whz.text: With support from the porcelain-obsessed
Referred to as the ‘Ming gap’ (ca.
1370– 1570) by scholars like Roxanna Brown, these interruptions occurred between 1325 and 1380.
The second severe shortage of blue-and-white porcelain saw China’s market share of ceramic production decrease to $50\%$ from 1368 to 1424–1430.
chunks: The second severe shortage of blue-and-white porcelain caused China's market share of ceramic production to decrease to 50%.
China's market share of ceramic production decreased from 1368 to 1424–1430.

qzxf4whz.text: This decreased to $5\%$ from 1424–1430 to 1487, before rebounding during the reign of the Hongzhi emperor, and then declining once again until the formal rescinding of the haijin (‘sea ban’) in 1567.
chunks: The percentage decreased to 5% from 1424–1430 to 1487.
The percentage rebounded during the reign of the Hongzhi emperor.
The percentage declined once again until the formal rescinding of the haijin ('sea ban') in 1567.

qzxf4whz.text: with great ingenuity.

Lacking access to naturally occurring kaolin clay—a mineral rich in silicates that gives porcelain much of its strength—they emulated the beauty of pure white porcelain using white slip (a liquefied suspension of clay particles in water), often embellished with painted decoration in blue pigments derived from cobalt oxide (fig.
chunks: They lacked access to naturally occurring kaolin clay, a mineral rich in silicates that gives porcelain much of its strength.
They emulated the beauty of pure white porcelain using white slip, a liquefied suspension of clay particles in water.
White slip was often embellished with painted decoration in blue pigments derived from cobalt oxide.

qzxf4whz.text: Following the introduction of Chinese examples towards the end of the Tran dynasty (1225–1400), Vietnamese potters developed their own unique ceramics, which were more heavily potted than Chinese wares and slightly off-white in colour (fig.
chunks: Vietnamese potters developed their own unique ceramics following the introduction of Chinese examples towards the end of the Tran dynasty.
Vietnamese ceramics were more heavily potted than Chinese wares.
Vietnamese ceramics were slightly off-white in color.

qzxf4whz.text: Produced at major kiln sites like Chu Dou and Bát Tràng near Hanoi, these wares benefited from the first of several interruptions to porcelain production in China, brought about by social unrest and dynastic change, and by the fifteenth century formed part of a lively intra-Asian trade in ceramics with Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines.
chunks: These wares were produced at major kiln sites like Chu Dou and Bát Tràng near Hanoi.
These wares benefited from the first of several interruptions to porcelain production in China, brought about by social unrest and dynastic change.
By the fifteenth century, these wares formed part of a lively intra-Asian trade in ceramics with Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

qzxf4whz.text: On China’s borders, nearly five centuries of Goryeo dynasty (918–1392) rule in Korea saw blue-green celadons inspired by wares from China become the dominant type of ceramics produced on the peninsula.
chunks: Nearly five centuries of Goryeo dynasty rule in Korea lasted from 918 to 1392.
During the Goryeo dynasty, blue-green celadons inspired by wares from China became the dominant type of ceramics produced on the Korean peninsula.

qzxf4whz.text: And Korean potters, many of whom arrived during two invasions of Korea led by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the 1590s, took an active role in the development of porcelain production in Japan.
chunks: Korean potters arrived in Japan during two invasions of Korea led by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the 1590s.
Korean potters took an active role in the development of porcelain production in Japan.

qzxf4whz.text: The early porcelain wares they produced, called Imari after a port near kilns in Arita, had a coarse, grainy texture with fluid, free-form designs in various shades of blue.
chunks: The early porcelain wares produced in Arita were called Imari, named after a port near the kilns.
The early porcelain wares had a coarse, grainy texture.
The early porcelain wares featured fluid, free-form designs in various shades of blue.

qzxf4whz.text: They were influenced by both Korean and Chinese monochrome porcelain and less formal blue-andwhite wares from southern Chinese kilns—the latter export wares that were made to conform to the aesthetic of the Japanese tea ceremony.
chunks: They were influenced by Korean monochrome porcelain.
They were influenced by Chinese monochrome porcelain.
They were influenced by less formal blue-and-white wares from southern Chinese kilns.
The export wares from southern Chinese kilns were made to conform to the aesthetic of the Japanese tea ceremony.

qzxf4whz.text: Later Imari wares were consciously designed to cater to Western tastes and became much more colourful and regimented, at times achieving more access in Europe than their Chinese counterparts.
chunks: Later Imari wares were consciously designed to cater to Western tastes.
Later Imari wares became much more colourful and regimented.
Later Imari wares at times achieved more access in Europe than their Chinese counterparts.

qzxf4whz.text: Augustus II the Strong of Saxony (who on his death in 1733 owned 35,798 pieces of porcelain; the largest collection in Europe), Böttger established a factory at Meissen, just outside Dresden, in 1710, and was soon producing large amounts of hard-paste porcelain.

qzxf4whz.text: In the 1720s, the Meissen factory developed a new and extensive range of enamel colours, and the factory’s painters excelled in fantastic depictions of life in an imagined Far East.

qzxf4whz.text: A number of other factories opened in Germany in the 1740s and ’50s, often with workers from Meissen or Vienna who provided the necessary technical expertise.

qzxf4whz.text: In Italy, where softpaste porcelain (an imitation, low-fired porcelain that lacked the ingredients found in hard-paste porcelain) had been made at the Medici workshops since the late sixteenth century, Francesco Vezzi established a porcelain factory in Venice that began producing hard-paste porcelain in significant numbers in 1720.

qzxf4whz.text: It remained at the forefront of European porcelain production for the rest of the century.

qzxf4whz.text: Across the channel, English manufacturers struggled to discover the secrets of making porcelain without access to the necessary ingredients, and between the 1740s and 1760s were only able to develop formulae that created a range of soft-paste porcelains unsuitable for tableware.

qzxf4whz.text: This changed after the discovery of kaolin clay in Cornwall in 1746 by an English chemist named William Cookworthy, who soon found even better-quality clay in St Stephen’s, near St Austell.

qzxf4whz.text: After two decades of experimentation, Cookworthy patented his recipe for making porcelain and established the Plymouth China factory in 1768—the first in England to manufacture hard-paste porcelain.

qzxf4whz.text: By the turn of the century, England had a flourishing porcelain industry, with factories in Derby, Worcester, Staffordshire, Liverpool and elsewhere.

qzxf4whz.text: Primarily commercial ventures that operated without noble or royal financial support, they were run by entrepreneurs and artisans, and much of their output was aimed at a growing middle class.

qzxf4whz.text: The European factories were so successful that eventually the demand for Chinese porcelain began to diminish, and towards the end of the eighteenth century the trade fell into serious decline.

qzxf4whz.text: But centuries of genuine artistic exchange stimulated by the trade in porcelain had left an indelible mark on the arts of Europe.

eborpipm.text: Perhaps the first truly global commodity, blue-and-white porcelain reached a wider audience than any other type of Chinese ceramic.

eborpipm.text: Sent to markets in Southeast Asia, Japan, Korea, India, the Middle East and even Africa, it inspired potters in major ceramic centres to produce elegant ceramics of their own design; from the rich turquoise fritwares of fifteenth-century Iznik, to elaborately panelled Japanese kraak wares from seventeenth century Arita.

eborpipm.text: Blue-and-white porcelain was also the first to be collected in Europe in large numbers, sparking a craze for things Chinese in the sixteenth century that would last well into the nineteenth, as new generations of artists and collectors rediscovered and renewed the art form.

eborpipm.text: The earliest surviving Chinese blue-and-white ceramics were made in the Tang period, when kilns in northern China dominated the production of both high-fired white stonewares and porcelains.

eborpipm.text: A shared creation of China and the Islamic Middle East, they were decorated with cobalt blue imported from northeast Persia or the Arabian Peninsula, using decorative techniques invented by potters in Basra, Iraq to embellish tin-glazed earthenwares.

eborpipm.text: These earthenwares were themselves developed in imitation of Chinese white wares, demonstrating the remarkable hybridity of early ceramic industries in Asia.

eborpipm.text: Tang blue-and-white ceramics represented a brief period of experimentation that was not repeated until the fourteenth century, when strong familial, cultural and economic ties to the Islamic world and the stabilisation of overland trade routes under the Mongol-led Yuan dynasty opened new markets and made access to imported cobalt easier.

eborpipm.text: Yuan imperial patronage turned the kilns of Jingdezhen in Jiangxi province into the largest porcelain production centre in China.

eborpipm.text: Combined with a cultural policy that promoted artistic exchange between different ethnic groups, this patronage created an atmosphere of experimentation that allowed new forms and styles to develop, including highly finished works intended for the court and less formal wares for the export market, transported along the silk road and from major ports like Canton and Quanzhou.

to0z3k87.text: Innovations in the Kangxi period, such as the addition of opaque white (derived from lead arsenate) and transparent ruby enamel (from colloidal gold), led to the development of new variations of wucai, such as famille rose, which were highly prized in Europe.

xmttco9e.text: Like wucai, doucai (‘fitted-colour’) porcelains are decorated with a combination of underglaze blue and overglaze enamels.

xmttco9e.text: However, while on wucai porcelain underglaze dark blue is applied in bold washes to complement strong overglaze colours, usually within outlines in red, brown or black, doucai porcelain features pale enamel washes with outlines in soft underglaze blue.

xmttco9e.text: It has been used to great effect on this bowl to depict mandarin ducks in a lotus pond, framed by a band of stylised, possibly Sanskrit, characters on the rim.
chunks: The decoration has been used to depict mandarin ducks in a lotus pond on this bowl.

xmttco9e.text: Since they were mistakenly thought to mate for life, pairs of mandarin ducks are an auspicious symbol for a happy marriage in China.
chunks: Mandarin ducks were mistakenly thought to mate for life.

xmttco9e.text: When accompanied by lotuses, homophonous in Chinese with the word for harmony (he), they may also be interpreted as expressing the wish for many sons, and ceramics pairing the two motifs have their origins in the decorative arts of the Tang dynasty.

bqe1w559.text: Centuries before the flowering of blue-and-white wares in the fourteenth century, large kiln sites in northern and southern China were producing glazed porcelain and stoneware in various shades of blue, green and white, which were adorned with elegant incised decoration.
chunks: Large kiln sites in northern and southern China were producing glazed porcelain and stoneware in various shades of blue, green, and white centuries before the flowering of blue-and-white wares in the fourteenth century.
The porcelain and stoneware produced were adorned with elegant incised decoration.

bqe1w559.text: Some of the most famous of these include qingbai (‘green-white’), a translucent porcelain with a bluish-green glaze produced at kiln complexes in Jingdezhen and Jizhou, and celadon, a type of porcelain or stoneware with an olive-green glaze that takes its name from a character with a distinctive outfit in L’Astrée, a seventeenthcentury French comedy.
chunks: Qingbai, also known as 'green-white,' is a translucent porcelain with a bluish-green glaze produced at kiln complexes in Jingdezhen and Jizhou.
Celadon is a type of porcelain or stoneware with an olive-green glaze.
Celadon takes its name from a character with a distinctive outfit in L’Astrée, a seventeenth-century French comedy.

bqe1w559.text: Similar in colour to valuable jade, these ceramics were among the most highly regarded in China—particularly celadon from the Longquan kilns in Lishui, Zhejiang province, which supplied the Southern Song court after the collapse of the northern dynasty in 1127.
chunks: These ceramics were similar in color to valuable jade.
These ceramics were among the most highly regarded in China.
Celadon from the Longquan kilns in Lishui, Zhejiang province was particularly highly regarded.
The Longquan kilns supplied the Southern Song court after the collapse of the northern dynasty in 1127.

bqe1w559.text: Today, some scholars prefer the term ‘greenware’ for these ceramics to avoid using arbitrary Western nomenclature.
chunks: Some scholars prefer the term 'greenware' for these ceramics to avoid using arbitrary Western nomenclature.

bqe1w559.text: Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were also exported to East Asia, Southeast Asia and the Islamic world—where the latter was thought to break or change colour if touched by poison.
chunks: Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were exported to East Asia.
Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were exported to Southeast Asia.
Chinese qingbai and celadon wares were exported to the Islamic world.
Celadon wares in the Islamic world were thought to break or change colour if touched by poison.

bqe1w559.text: They were most eagerly collected in regions situated firmly within China’s sphere of cultural and political influence, such as Japan.
chunks: Artifacts were most eagerly collected in regions situated firmly within China’s sphere of cultural and political influence.
Japan was a region situated firmly within China’s sphere of cultural and political influence.

bqe1w559.text: Song dynasty celadon shipped from Ningbo in Zhejiang province to Japan.
chunks: Song dynasty celadon was shipped from Ningbo in Zhejiang province to Japan.

bqe1w559.text: During the Kamakura period (1185–1333), celadon became the favoured form of utensils and interior decoration for the Japanese tea ceremony, and formed part of a fashion for karamono (‘Chinese things’), attested to by the thousands of shards recovered from historic sites and many intact examples preserved in major Japanese temples.
chunks: During the Kamakura period, celadon became the favored form of utensils and interior decoration for the Japanese tea ceremony.
Celadon formed part of a fashion for karamono, meaning 'Chinese things'.
The popularity of celadon is attested to by thousands of shards recovered from historic sites.
Many intact examples of celadon are preserved in major Japanese temples.

bqe1w559.text: In Korea, refined Chinese celadon pieces brought to the imperial court by official embassies in the Goryeo period (918–1392) were seen as the pinnacle of ceramic artistry.
chunks: Refined Chinese celadon pieces were brought to the imperial court by official embassies in Korea during the Goryeo period (918–1392).
Refined Chinese celadon pieces were seen as the pinnacle of ceramic artistry in Korea during the Goryeo period (918–1392).

bqe1w559.text: Local potters were soon making their own versions, combining stylistic elements drawn directly from Chinese wares as well as new designs articulated for Korean consumers.
chunks: Local potters were soon making their own versions of pottery.
Local potters combined stylistic elements drawn directly from Chinese wares.
Local potters created new designs articulated for Korean consumers.

bqe1w559.text: And in Mainland Southeast Asia, green-glazed ceramics reminiscent of celadon were among the first stonewares to be produced,
using kiln technologies from China that allowed ceramics to be fired at much higher temperatures.

They were made at a number of sites in Vietnam along the Red River Delta during the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, and most famously at Sawankhalok in the fifteenth century, when they formed one of the early Thai kingdom’s most important export commodities.
chunks: Ceramics were made at a number of sites in Vietnam along the Red River Delta during the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries.
Ceramics were most famously made at Sawankhalok in the fifteenth century.
Ceramics formed one of the early Thai kingdom's most important export commodities during the fifteenth century.

bqe1w559.text: This absence was most likely the result of changing fashions in Asia.
chunks: The absence was most likely the result of changing fashions in Asia.

bqe1w559.text: By the time Europe began direct trade with China in the sixteenth century, celadon wares had largely been supplanted in the domestic market by blue-and-white porcelain.
chunks: By the sixteenth century, Europe began direct trade with China.
Celadon wares had largely been supplanted in the domestic market by blue-and-white porcelain.

bqe1w559.text: Established kilns that had focused on celadon before the fourteenth century turned their attention to the production of blue-and-white wares—although some—such as the kilns in Longquan, Cizhou and Jizhou—continued to produce celadon and other monochromatic ceramics in smaller quantities, and Song examples remained popular among collectors in later periods.
chunks: Established kilns that had focused on celadon before the fourteenth century turned their attention to the production of blue-and-white wares.
Some kilns, such as those in Longquan, Cizhou, and Jizhou, continued to produce celadon and other monochromatic ceramics in smaller quantities.
Song examples of celadon and monochromatic ceramics remained popular among collectors in later periods.

bqe1w559.text: Qingbai is also referred to as yingqing (‘shadow green’), although this name appears only to date from the eighteenth century.
chunks: Qingbai is also referred to as yingqing (‘shadow green’).
The name yingqing (‘shadow green’) appears only to date from the eighteenth century.

bqe1w559.text: Other theories for the origin of celadon suggest that the name is a corruption of ‘Saladin’, the Ayyubid Sultan, who in 1171 sent forty pieces of the ceramic to the Sultan of Syria, or that it derives from the Sanskrit words sila and dhara, which mean ‘green’ and ‘stone’.
chunks: Some theories suggest that the name celadon is a corruption of 'Saladin', the Ayyubid Sultan.
Saladin sent forty pieces of the ceramic to the Sultan of Syria in 1171.
Other theories suggest that the name celadon derives from the Sanskrit words sila and dhara.
The Sanskrit words sila and dhara mean 'green' and 'stone'.

xmzy68s9.text: Celadon was never sent to Europe in significant numbers, nor were they ever made with Western consumers in mind.
chunks: Celadon was never sent to Europe in significant numbers.

xmzy68s9.text: The rare examples that did arrive were diplomatic gifts from rulers in the Islamic world, which were sometimes given elaborate metalwork mounts.

xmzy68s9.text: Only three surviving Chinese ceramic pieces can be documented as reaching Europe before 1500: the Fonthill Vase (now in Dublin), which is qingbai; a Longquan celadon dish presented to Lorenzo de’ Medici by the Mamluk Sultan of Egypt in 1487; and the ‘Katzenelnbogen bowl’, bought by an aristocratic German pilgrim in the Holy Land in 1433–1434, who on his return had it given a cover and mounts in gilded silver.
chunks: Only three surviving Chinese ceramic pieces can be documented as reaching Europe before 1500.

The ‘Katzenelnbogen bowl’ was bought by an aristocratic German pilgrim in the Holy Land in 1433–1434.
The ‘Katzenelnbogen bowl’ was given a cover and mounts in gilded silver upon the pilgrim's return.

o8vr9ndw.text: Their icy blue-green tinge was produced by applying a glaze with small amounts of iron to a fine porcelain stone and kaolin clay body, which was fired in an oxygen deprived atmosphere.

fb2osf2j.text: Adopting a technique used to manufacture Ding wares in northern China, qingbai bowls and dishes were often fired upside down in the kiln.

fb2osf2j.text: This saved space in the kiln by allowing for everted vessels to be stacked in a pile, and was essential for mass produced utilitarian and export wares.

fb2osf2j.text: It also helped to evenly spread the weight of each vessel around the rim, preventing deformation and allowing for more thinly potted bodies.
